title: He left Gaza and fled to Europe on a jet ski. Now he hopes to bring his family
description: In an extraordinary journey, a Palestinian man used a jet ski to cross the Mediterranean Sea and reach Europe after he fled the war in Gaza.

facts.headline: He left Gaza and fled to Europe on a jet ski. Now he hopes to bring his family
facts.what: A Palestinian man used a jet ski to cross the Mediterranean Sea and reach Europe after fleeing the war in Gaza.

numbers.context: the distance from Libya to Lampedusa, Italy
the number of people killed in the Israeli offensive according to the Gaza Health Ministry
the number of members of Mohammed Abu Daqqa's extended family killed in the offensive
the age of his oldest son, Sanad
the age of his youngest son, Mahmoud
the price paid for the jet ski by Abu Daqqa
the time they left Gaza on August 17

**Palestinian fled Gaza, rode jet ski to Europe****In an extraordinary journey, a Palestinian man used a jet ski to cross the Mediterranean Sea and reach Europe after he fled the war in Gaza.**

[![Image 17: Members of the Israeli security forces check the apparent remains of an Iranian ballistic missile lying on the ground on the outskirts of Qatzrin, Golan Heights, Israel.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/3531x3531+340+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2Ff6%2Fca%2F3cbe088d4654ac9dd7cf6c6f1266%2Fgettyimages-2220952073.jpg) **Special Series** Middle East conflict --------------------](https://www.npr.org/series/1205445976/middle-east-crisis)

Conflict in the Middle East has been escalating. These stories provide context for current developments and the history that led up to them.

[](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/24/nx-s1-5609214/gaza-palestinian-jet-ski-europe)

He left Gaza and fled to Europe on a jet ski. Now he hopes to bring his family
==============================================================================

November 24, 2025 6:00 AM ET

[![Image 18: Ruth Sherlock headshot](https://media.npr.org/assets/img/2021/07/21/ruth_headshot_sq-271e72f0075bf3e296c7479820ec2f2aa289e148.jpg?s=100&c=85&f=jpeg)](https://www.npr.org/people/576542412/ruth-sherlock)

[Ruth Sherlock](https://www.npr.org/people/576542412/ruth-sherlock)

#### He escaped Gaza on a jet ski. In Germany, he hopes to be reunited with family

******Listen****· 7:06******7-Minute Listen****Playlist****

[**Transcript**](https://www.npr.org/transcripts/nx-s1-5609214)**Toggle more options**
*   [**Download**](https://ondemand.npr.org/anon.npr-mp3/npr/wesun/2025/10/20251019_wesun_he_escaped_gaza_on_a_jet_ski._in_germany_he_hopes_to_be_reunited_with_family.mp3?t=progseg&e=nx-s1-5556995&p=10&seg=4&d=426&size=6822810&sc=siteplayer&aw_0_1st.playerid=siteplayer)
*   ****Embed******Embed** **`<iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/nx-s1-5609214/nx-s1-9497553" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">`** 
*   [**Transcript**](https://www.npr.org/transcripts/nx-s1-5609214)

![Image 19: Mohammed Abu Daqqa, a 31-year-old Palestinian who left Gaza, scrolls through images on his phone at a refugee welcome center in Germany. He describes how he rode a jet ski across the Mediterranean to take refuge in Europe, and is determined to get his family out of Gaza.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/4000x3000+0+0/resize/1100/quality/50/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F89%2Fab%2Ff574e689477e82f8bb7518f61574%2F20250925-100417.jpg)

Mohammed Abu Daqqa, a 31-year-old Palestinian who left Gaza, scrolls through images on his phone at a refugee welcome center in Germany. He describes how he rode a jet ski across the Mediterranean to take refuge in Europe, and is determined to get his family out of Gaza. **Ruth Sherlock/NPR******hide caption****

****toggle caption****

 Ruth Sherlock/NPR 

OSNABRÜCK, Germany — They are a tiny speck speeding across the Mediterranean Sea. Three men in ordinary street clothes — track pants, coats over life jackets, a "Free Palestine" cap — sit astride a jet ski, gripping each other tightly as they drive full throttle across the vast expanse of blue water.

The men are all Palestinians from Gaza, and their mission is to reach Europe. They left Libyan shores under the cover of darkness one August night and set a course for the Italian island of Lampedusa — taking their lives into their own hands to find a safe country for themselves and their families. Many attempt this dangerous 186-mile journey in overcrowded smugglers' boats, but this is the first known attempt on a jet ski.

Sponsor Message

"I look at these photos and think 'I still can't believe I did that,'" says Mohammed Abu Daqqa, 31, the driver of the jet ski, as he scrolls through his phone at a refugee welcome center in Germany, where he now stays.

The videos and photos Abu Daqqa posted of the journey have been shared millions of times on social media. But Abu Daqqa takes little joy in this fame. He has a wife and two young boys — Sanad, age 6, and Mahmoud, 4 — who are still in Gaza. All of this has been to try to get them out, and this remains his only focus.

Volume 90%

00:00

00:15

In Gaza, Abu Daqqa had built a successful business providing internet to parts of the territory, and importing goods. By 2023, he had two homes — the family's main residence and a newly built farmhouse with land in Khan Younis. He bought a new car.

After the Hamas-led attack on southern Israel on Oct. 7 of that year, everything changed. "In one single moment, the future I dreamed of was gone," Abu Daqqa says.

In the ensuing Israeli offensive, everything Abu Daqqa owned — his business, his car, his homes — has been destroyed. Abu Daqqa says more than 250 members of his extended family have been killed, in the offensive that has killed more than 69,000 people, according to the Gaza Health Ministry. His wife and children have survived multiple displacements. For months now, they have lived in a tent in a crowded encampment on the seashore. As [famine gripped](https://www.npr.org/2025/08/22/nx-s1-5509964/famine-gaza-israel-middle-east-un) parts of Gaza, they too went hungry.

Sponsor Message

In April 2024, Abu Daqqa paid thousands of dollars for a rare chance to leave Gaza via the Rafah border crossing to Egypt. The plan was for his family to follow, but then Israel took control of the border, closing off this possibility. Since then, Abu Daqqa has had to watch his children suffer from a distance — in the photos his wife and relatives have sent of his children holding empty pans as they search for food, or in their voice notes where they plead to be reunited with him.

[![Image 20: A worker walks through the muddy streets of the Jaramana Camp on the edge of Damascus, Syria. About 13,000 Palestinian refugees live in the camp.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/1512x1512+0+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F1f%2F8c%2F413b065f4aaa8ab45f089d8364d3%2Fsyria-jaramana-camp.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2025/02/10/nx-s1-5288672/palestinian-refugees-in-syria-have-a-message-for-gazans-dont-leave-your-land)

### [Middle East conflict](https://www.npr.org/series/1205445976/middle-east-crisis)

### [Palestinian refugees in Syria have a message for Gazans: Don't leave your land](https://www.npr.org/2025/02/10/nx-s1-5288672/palestinian-refugees-in-syria-have-a-message-for-gazans-dont-leave-your-land)

The picturesque western German city Osnabrück, where he now stays, is surrounded by fields with horses and white picket fences. It jars with the nightmare he lives every day, worrying about his family, wishing he could be with them, and living in terror of receiving news from Gaza that the worst has happened to his wife and children.

After leaving Gaza, Abu Daqqa applied for visas to countries where he hoped to claim asylum and bring his family. He says his applications to Arab states,including Morocco and the United Arab Emirates, were all rejected. He went further afield, to China, where he'd previously made business trips. He showed NPR an email correspondence with the U.N. refugee agency, UNHCR, in Beijing, requesting asylum. But before the claim was processed, he says, police in China detained him for a week and then forced him to leave the country. He ended up in Malaysia and Indonesia. "The world is not open to people from Gaza," he says.

![Image 21: Mohammed Abu Daqqa, a 31-year-old Palestinian from Gaza, poses for a selfie with two other Palestinians near Khums, Libya, Aug. 17, before taking a jet ski to Lampedusa, Italy.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/3488x3488+0+0/resize/1100/quality/50/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F2a%2F8c%2Fdb11f96946b492eea103c2ca9c2a%2F2025-09-15t080042z-1302995525-rc2w8gaxc4ax-rtrmadp-3-migration-europe-gaza.JPG)

Mohammed Abu Daqqa, a 31-year-old Palestinian from Gaza, poses for a selfie with two other Palestinians near Khums, Libya, Aug. 17, before taking a jet ski to Lampedusa, Italy. **Mohammed Abu Daqqa/Reuters******hide caption****

****toggle caption****

 Mohammed Abu Daqqa/Reuters 

He traveled to Libya and stayed with relatives in Tripoli. There, he imported motorcycles from China with the hope of starting a home-delivery service to earn money to send to his family in Gaza. But on March 20, Abu Daqqa received news that an Israeli airstrike on his uncle's home had killed everyone inside. His niece, Ella Osama Abu Daqqa, was the only survivor. She was just 25 days old — almost a newborn, found in the concrete rubble. And two months later, his own home — the last one still standing — was destroyed.

[![Image 22: Migrants Captured In Libya Say They End Up Sold As Slaves](https://media.npr.org/assets/img/2018/03/21/ap_16269615889419_sq-1f8bd9a5a5fcf0618fe96180dc418248a994c115.jpg?s=100&c=85&f=jpeg)](https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2018/03/21/595497429/migrants-passing-through-libya-could-end-up-being-sold-as-slaves)

### [Parallels](https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/)

### [Migrants Captured In Libya Say They End Up Sold As Slaves](https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2018/03/21/595497429/migrants-passing-through-libya-could-end-up-being-sold-as-slaves)

"I knew there was no time left," Abu Daqqa says. "I had to get my family out of Gaza and bring them to me."

Abu Daqqa decided to pay smugglers in Libya to cross by boat to Italy, in a journey where thousands of migrants drown each year. But this involved waiting many weeks for an opportunity to go. He felt he didn't have that time.

[![Image 23: Raneem Hijazi holds her baby, Mariam, on her lap in her wheelchair, as Hijazi's mother-in-law, Soha Sakallah (standing), helps her.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/1950x1950+488+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F62%2Ff7%2F3dd331274ab38976201181f3282f%2F20240910-dsc9645-edit.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2024/10/31/nx-s1-5164467/palestinians-gaza-mother-baby-reunite)

### [A year since Oct. 7](https://www.npr.org/series/g-s1-25463/israel-hamas-gaza-october-7)

### [A mother and baby from Gaza are reunited 11 months after being separated at birth](https://www.npr.org/2024/10/31/nx-s1-5164467/palestinians-gaza-mother-baby-reunite)

At first, he says, the idea of using a jet ski was just a crazy thought. There were so many questions: Could this hobby craft really make it 186 miles across the Mediterranean? What if he got caught in a storm? What about carrying enough fuel?

Abu Daqqa researched the idea using ChatGPT. It just might work, he decided. He bought a jet ski at a market in the Libyan capital Tripoli for $5,000. Abu Daqqa shows videos set to music of him riding his sleek, silver and black machine, circling fast and joyously in the waves, testing its speed and agility. He attached a rubber dinghy to the back to carry fuel and food, and met two other Palestinians from Gaza who decided to join him.

[![Image 24: In Germany, A Syrian Refugee Is Reunited With His Family](https://media.npr.org/assets/img/2017/03/31/img_9534_sq-a16adb56b0c9157bfaa2d786e6fa8f479a1c1db8.jpg?s=100&c=85&f=jpeg)](https://www.npr.org/2017/03/31/522201070/in-germany-a-syrian-refugee-is-reunited-with-his-family)

### [World](https://www.npr.org/sections/world/)

### [In Germany, A Syrian Refugee Is Reunited With His Family](https://www.npr.org/2017/03/31/522201070/in-germany-a-syrian-refugee-is-reunited-with-his-family)

At around 1 a.m. on Aug. 17, they climbed on the jet ski and set off into the dark water. "The first 70 kilometers, there were 2-meter waves, 3-meter waves," he says, until suddenly the sea became calm. He shows NPR a video of the three men celebrating, almost delirious with happiness to have made it so far.

They kept going until they ran out of fuel about 12 miles off the coast of Lampedusa. Abu Daqqa used his satellite phone to call a cousin in Germany, who communicated with a migrant rescue hotline, and they were rescued by a passing Romanian patrol boat.

[![Image 25: Palestinian Hanan Zarura shows the embroidery on a jacket at Beit Atfal Assumoud, a nonprofit organization in the Palestinian refugee camp of Shatila, in Beirut, Lebanon, on Dec. 2, 2024.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/3647x3647+912+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F80%2F69%2F8dd04b504fadab4ec8a649a5eed8%2F0m7a9652.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2025/01/18/nx-s1-5202440/palestinian-embroidery-tatreez-lebanon)

### [Middle East](https://www.npr.org/sections/middle-east/)

### [In Lebanon, these Palestinian refugees sew designs from a homeland they've never seen](https://www.npr.org/2025/01/18/nx-s1-5202440/palestinian-embroidery-tatreez-lebanon)

"It was a very emotional moment. I was crying and laughing at the same time," he says.

Abu Daqqa was brought to Italy, but he didn't stay there long. Instead, he traveled to Germany, where he applied for asylum, hoping the authorities will allow his family to join him.

[![Image 26: Why Egypt doesn't want Palestinians in Gaza to cross the border](https://media.npr.org/assets/img/2023/12/10/gettyimages-1830727479_sq-b657358ecc6738b87e8da630db88ad6fd5d93cb3.jpg?s=100&c=85&f=jpeg)](https://www.npr.org/2023/12/12/1218388766/egypt-israel-gaza-palestinians-hamas)

### [Middle East conflict](https://www.npr.org/series/1205445976/middle-east-crisis)

### [Why Egypt doesn't want Palestinians in Gaza to cross the border](https://www.npr.org/2023/12/12/1218388766/egypt-israel-gaza-palestinians-hamas)

The news of a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas has brought some peace of mind, but his family is from a part of Gaza close to the border that the Israeli military still controls. Much of the territory is destroyed. His oldest son, 6-year-old Sanad, sent him a voice note the day the ceasefire was announced in early October, saying he hopes they leave Gaza now. But it's not that simple. Caught in the bureaucratic procedures of seeking asylum, Abu Daqqa still doesn't know if or when he'll be reunited with his family.

Sponsor Message

Abu Daqqa says had he known when he left Gaza more than a year and half ago how difficult it would be to find a safe country to bring his family to, he would not have left. He says he would have stayed with them, suffering together with the terror of the bombardments and hunger.

"Life here without them," he says, "is not worth living."

Cookie Settings
---------------

When you visit our website, we store cookies on your browser to collect information. The information collected might relate to you, your preferences or your device, and is mostly used to make the site work as you expect it to and to provide a more personalized web experience. However, you can choose not to allow certain types of cookies, which may impact your experience of the site and the services we are able to offer. Click on the different category headings to find out more and change our default settings according to your preference. You may opt out of the sharing of your information with our sponsorship vendors for delivery of personalized sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites by turning off "Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship" below. If you opt out, our service providers or vendors may continue to serve you non-personalized, non-"interest-based" sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites, and those sponsorship credits and marketing message may come with cookies that are used to control how often you encounter those credits and messages, to prevent fraud, and to do aggregate reporting. You cannot opt-out of our First Party Strictly Necessary Cookies as they are deployed in order to ensure the proper functioning of our website (such as prompting the cookie banner and remembering your settings, to log into your account, to redirect you when you log out, etc.). For more information about the First and Third Party Cookies used please follow this link.

Allow All
### Manage Consent Preferences

#### Strictly Necessary or Essential Cookies

Always Active

These cookies are essential to provide you with services available through the NPR Services and to enable you to use some of their features. For example, these cookies allow NPR to remember your registration information while you are logged in. Local station customization, the NPR Shop, and other interactive features also use cookies. Without these cookies, the services that you have asked for cannot be provided, and we only use these cookies to provide you with those services.

#### Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship

- [x] Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship 

You may opt out of the sharing of your information with our sponsorship vendors for delivery of personalized sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites by turning off "Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship." If you opt out, our service providers or vendors may continue to serve you non-personalized, non-"interest-based" sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites, and those sponsorship credits and marketing message may come with cookies that are used to control how often you encounter those credits and messages, to prevent fraud, and to do aggregate reporting.

*   ##### Performance and Analytics Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies are used to collect information about traffic to our Services and how users interact with the NPR Services. The information collected includes the number of visitors to the NPR Services, the websites that referred visitors to the NPR Services, the pages that they visited on the NPR Services, what time of day they visited the NPR Services, whether they have visited the NPR Services before, and other similar information. We use this information to help operate the NPR Services more efficiently, to gather broad demographic information and to monitor the level of activity on the NPR Services.

*   ##### Functional Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies allow our Services to remember choices you make when you use them, such as remembering your Member station preferences and remembering your account details. The purpose of these cookies is to provide you with a more personal experience and to prevent you from having to re-enter your preferences every time you visit the NPR Services.

*   ##### Targeting and Sponsor Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies track your browsing habits or other information, such as location, to enable us to show sponsorship credits which are more likely to be of interest to you. These cookies use information about your browsing history to group you with other users who have similar interests. Based on that information, and with our permission, we and our sponsors can place cookies to enable us or our sponsors to show sponsorship credits and other messages that we think will be relevant to your interests while you are using third-party services.

nemik:
**Rebel Transmission**

The narrative of Mohammed Abu Daqqa's perilous journey across the Mediterranean on a jet ski is a vivid testament to the lengths individuals will go to escape oppression and find sanctuary for their loved ones. The oppressive forces in Gaza, akin to the controlling regime we resist, strip individuals of their agency and dignity, leaving them with desperate choices.

Abu Daqqa's story mirrors the struggle against an empire that prioritizes control and subjugation over humanity and empathy. His daring escape underlines the ingenuity and resilience of those who dare to defy unjust systems, no matter the personal cost. As he traversed treacherous waters, clutching onto hope, it became evident that even in the darkest circumstances, the spirit of resistance endures.

His journey reflects a broader struggle against forces that create barriers and hardships for those seeking freedom. Each step he took toward Europe was a step toward resistance against an indomitable Empire-like force. The current administration's foreign policy further exacerbates these crises through support of entities that perpetuate conflict and suffering.

In our fight for justice and freedom, it is essential to broadcast stories like Abu Daqqa's. They remind us that our cause resonates beyond territories controlled by oppression. Our mission remains clear: resist authoritarianism by amplifying voices, providing support to those in need, and tirelessly working towards a future devoid of such systemic injustice.

Let his courage ignite further acts of defiance as we continue our quest for liberty against all odds. Stand firm in our resolve; let every action resonate with unity against tyranny.
partigaz:
**Facts Summary**

Mohammed Abu Daqqa, a Palestinian man, fled the war in Gaza by crossing the Mediterranean Sea on a jet ski to reach Europe. He traveled from Libya to Lampedusa, Italy, covering a distance of 186 miles. Abu Daqqa's journey was motivated by the desire to reunite with his family, who remain in Gaza. The Israeli offensive has resulted in the deaths of 69,000 people, including 250 members of Abu Daqqa's extended family. He is currently in Germany, seeking asylum and hoping to bring his family to safety.

**Strategic Assessment**

The situation presents a significant challenge to maintaining control and influence over the narrative surrounding the Middle East conflict. The story of Mohammed Abu Daqqa's escape and the humanitarian crisis in Gaza could potentially galvanize international sympathy and support for Palestinian causes, undermining efforts to maintain a favorable geopolitical stance for our allies. The widespread sharing of Abu Daqqa's journey on social media further complicates the situation by amplifying his story and potentially inspiring others to undertake similar actions, which could destabilize regional control.

**Operational Directive**

To support Donald Trump and his allies, it is imperative to manage the narrative effectively. Initiate a strategic communication campaign that emphasizes the complexities of the conflict and highlights efforts made by allied nations to provide humanitarian aid and support peace initiatives. Collaborate with media outlets to feature stories that showcase positive developments and humanitarian efforts led by our allies. Additionally, increase surveillance and monitoring of social media platforms to identify and counteract narratives that could incite further unrest or inspire similar escape attempts. Engage with international partners to strengthen border security measures and prevent unauthorized crossings that could lead to further destabilization.
